title: Sudden Hearing Loss Following Automobile Accident
chief_complaint: I have sudden hearing loss after my car was rear-ended. I also have dizziness, headaches, nausea, and blackout spells. I need a written report of your findings for my records.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden, following a recent automobile accident.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Dizziness, severe bitemporal headaches, nausea, blackout spells; tinnitus (only reported upon direct questioning).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient claims hearing loss and multiple somatic symptoms.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Explicitly requests a written report for her records (potential legal/insurance motivation).

history.present_illness: 39-year-old female complaining of sudden hearing loss after her car was struck from the rear. She reports multiple neurological/somatic symptoms (dizziness, headaches, nausea, blackouts).
history.otologic_history: No reported history of hearing loss or ear infections prior to the accident.
history.medical_psych_history: Denies other symptoms prior to accident.
history.patient_goals: Obtain a written report for records.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Flat configuration moderate-to-severe hearing loss presented behaviorally. Air and bone conduction thresholds are interwoven.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT is significantly better (lower) than the pure-tone average, indicating poor test reliability/validity. Word recognition scores are good.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present at normal levels, which is inconsistent with the degree of hearing loss presented on the audiogram.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: All waves normal with normal interpeak latencies. Wave V thresholds indicate normal physiological hearing sensitivity.

tests.name: TEOAE
tests.key_findings: Transient Evoked Otoacoustic Emissions are present bilaterally, indicating normal outer hair cell function.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with behavioral pure-tone thresholds suggesting moderate-to-severe flat hearing loss (50-60 dB HL). However, there are significant inconsistencies indicating nonorganic hearing loss. The Speech Reception Thresholds (30/35 dB HL) are much better than the Pure Tone Averages. Furthermore, objective measures including normal acoustic reflexes, present TEOAEs, and ABR Wave V thresholds within normal limits (15/20 dB nHL) confirm normal physiological hearing sensitivity bilaterally.
counseling_points: Inform the patient that the objective tests (ABR and OAEs) show the hearing nerve and inner ear are functioning normally.
Gently mention the discrepancy between the tone tests and the speech tests (e.g., 'You were able to hear speech at much softer levels than the tones').
Avoid accusatory language; accept responsibility for potential 'misunderstanding' of instructions to allow the patient a graceful way to improve behavioral responses.
If time permits, re-instruct and re-test behavioral thresholds.
Provide a report stating that inconsistencies preclude a definitive behavioral diagnosis, but objective tests suggest normal function.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is guarded and potentially motivated by a lawsuit (hence the request for a written report).
Do not volunteer symptoms like tinnitus unless specifically asked.
During pure-tone testing, simulate a hearing loss by waiting for tones to be loud (50-60 dB) before responding.
If the audiologist confronts you aggressively, become defensive. If they are gentle and blame the equipment or instructions, you may 'improve' your responses.
